questions.text: Which among the given options exhibits swarming behaviour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Proteus mirabilis

Explanation:

  • The image shows swarming behavior, characterized by the rapid movement and spreading of bacteria across a solid surface.
  • Proteus mirabilis is known for its distinctive swarming motility, where it forms concentric rings or bull's-eye patterns due to the coordinated movement of peritrichous flagella.
  • This motility allows Proteus mirabilis to migrate across surfaces, which is essential for its pathogenesis and survival in various environments.
  • Other examples: Vibrio parahaemolyticus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilis and Serratia liquefaciens

questions.text: Which of the following spores are commonly used for sterilization control in hot air ovens?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bacillus subtilis

 

Explanation:

Bacillus subtilis is commonly used as a biological indicator for hot air ovens because its spores are heat-resistant and can indicate whether the sterilization process effectively kills spores.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of spore formation (sporulation) in correct order:

choices.text: Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis
Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis
Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis ➔ Axial filament formation
Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex and coat formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

 

Explanation:

  • Axial filament formation: The bacterial cell prepares for sporulation by forming an axial filament, which helps organise the process.
  • Septum formation: Triggered by environmental conditions such as nutrient limitation or other stressors, the bacterium divides asymmetrically, forming a septum that separates the mother cell from the forespore.
  • Asymmetric division: One compartment becomes the smaller forespore (develops into the spore), and the other becomes the larger mother cell.
  • Engulfment: The mother cell engulfs the forespore within a second membrane.
  • Cortex formation: A thick layer of peptidoglycan forms between the two membranes of the spore.
  • Coat formation: Various proteins assemble around the spore, forming the coat.
  • Maturation and lysis: The spore matures, becoming highly resistant to environmental stresses.
    • Eventually, the mother cell lyses, releasing the mature spore into the environment.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is known for terminal spore formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Clostridium tetani

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clostridium tetani is a bacterium known for forming terminal spores.
  • Terminal spores are spores formed at the end of the bacterial cell,
  • These spores are resistant to heat, desiccation, and chemical agents, allowing the bacterium to survive adverse conditions.
  • Clostridium tetani specifically forms terminal spores as part of its life cycle, facilitating its ability to persist in the environment and cause tetanus in humans when spores enter wounds.

Spore Location

Examples

Central

Bacillus anthracis, Bacillus cereus

Terminal

Clostridium tetani

Subterminal

Bacillus thuringiensis, Bacillus subtilis, Clostridium botulinum, Clostridium perfringens


 

Bacillus anthracis (Option B) is a spore-forming bacterium but forms central spores, which are located more centrally within the bacterial cell.

The causative agent of anthrax.

 

Clostridium perfringens (Option C) is another spore-forming bacterium.

  • Instead, it forms subterminal spores, which are located near the end but not exactly at the terminal end of the bacterial cell.
  • It can cause food poisoning and gas gangrene.

 

Bacillus cereus (Option D) is a spore-forming bacterium that forms central spores that are not located at the terminal end of the bacterial cell.

  • It is known for causing food poisoning through the production of enterotoxins in contaminated food.

questions.text: Arrange the layers of a spore from outside to inside in the correct order:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Exosporium → Coat → Cortex → Core.

 

Explanation:

  • Exosporium: This is the outermost layer of a spore, consisting of proteins and sometimes lipids, providing protection against environmental factors.
  • Coat: Beneath the exosporium lies the spore coat, which is a thick layer made of peptidoglycan and proteins.
    • It provides structural support and resistance to chemicals.
  • Cortex: The cortex is located beneath the coat and consists of peptidoglycan.
    • It plays a role in maintaining spore dehydration and resistance.
  • Core: The innermost layer of a spore is the core, containing the spore's genetic material (DNA), ribosomes, and enzymes necessary for germination and metabolic activity.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding fimbriae/pili from the list below:


	Fimbriae are made of subunits called fibrillins.
	Pili are involved in bacterial conjugation.
	Pili can be involved in motility through a process known as "twitching."
	Fimbriae play a role in pellicle formation at the liquid-surface interface.
	Pili are longer and more numerous than flagella.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2, 3, and 4

 

Explanation:

Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins(Statement 1). They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella. (Statement 5)

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer. (Statement 2)

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility. (Statement 3)

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae. (Statement 4)

questions.text: Leifson and Ryu's stain is used for staining which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flagella

Explanation:

Leifson and Ryu's stain is specifically used for staining flagella, allowing them to be visualized under a dark field microscope.

  • Fungi (Option A): Fungi are typically stained using special fungal stains like lactophenol cotton blue or potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparations.
  • Mycobacteria (Option B): Mycobacteria are stained using acid-fast stains like Ziehl-Neelsen or Kinyoun stains due to their high lipid content in the cell wall.
  • Capsules (Option D): Capsules are often stained using India ink or special stains like Maneval's capsule stain to highlight their presence around bacterial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for the demonstration of bacterial motility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gram staining

 

Explanation:

  • Gram staining is a technique used to differentiate bacterial species into two groups based on the structural differences in their cell walls.
  • It does not provide information about bacterial motility.

 

Methods of demonstrating motility

  • Dark Field / Dark Ground microscopy: Flagella may sometimes be seen under dark-ground illumination, though this is unreliable due to their small size.
  • Special Staining Techniques: Mordanting techniques increase flagella thickness, making them visible under a light microscope. Eg: Leifson or Ryu's flagella staining techniques.
  • Electron Microscopy: Allows high-resolution visualization of flagella.
  • Semi-Solid Agar Medium: Motile bacteria exhibit spreading growth away from the inoculation site, unlike non-motile bacteria.
  • Hanging Drop Method: Observing a drop of bacterial suspension under a microscope can show motile bacteria moving.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contain a polysaccharide capsule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bacillus anthracis

 

Explanation:

Most of the bacterial capsules are polysaccharide in nature except in Bacillus anthracis where it is polypeptide in nature.

 

  • Bacteria often secrete a viscid material around their cell surface, called glycocalyx.
  • When the glycocalyx is organized into a defined structure, it is called a capsule, as in Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • When the glycocalyx layer is in the form of loose, undefined material, it is known as a slime layer, as seen in Leuconostoc.
  • Very thin capsules are termed microcapsules.
  • Certain bacteria, such as Streptococcus salivarius, possess both a capsule and a slime layer.

 

Capsulated Organisms

Polysaccharide Capsule

Exceptions
  • Pneumococcus
  • Meningococcus
  • Haemophilus influenzae (Option A)
  • Klebsiella pneumoniae (Option C)
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B)
  • Bacteroides fragilis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Bacillus anthracis - Polypeptide (glutamate) (Option D)
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (some strains) - Hyaluronic acid

questions.text: Which of the following organisms corresponds to the morphology of the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Spirillum volutans

Explanations:

Spirillum volutans possesses lophotrichous flagella, which are clusters of flagella located at one or both ends of the cell.

  • Escherichia coli (Option A): This bacterium typically has peritrichous flagella, meaning flagella are distributed all over the cell surface.

  • Vibrio cholerae (Option C): This bacterium typically has a monotrichous flagellum, meaning a single flagellum at one end.

  • Proteus (Option D): This bacterium also typically has peritrichous flagella, with flagella distributed around the entire cell surface.

Types of Flagella Based on Arrangement:

  • Monotrichous: A single flagellum at one end (e.g., Vibrio cholerae).
  • Lophotrichous: A tuft of flagella at one or both ends (e.g., Spirilla).
  • Amphitrichous: Flagella at both poles of the cell. (e.g., Campylobacter)
  • Peritrichous: Flagella arranged all around the cell (e.g., Proteus).

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is primarily responsible for recognising and binding to endotoxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)

Explanations:

  • Endotoxins bind to Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) on the surface of immune cells.
  • This binding initiates a signaling cascade that leads to the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
  • Upon activation, TLRs recruit adaptor proteins (proteins that mediate other protein-protein interactions) within the cytosol of the immune cell to propagate the antigen-induced signal transduction pathway.
  • These recruited proteins are then responsible for the subsequent activation of other downstream proteins, including protein kinases (IKKi, IRAK1, IRAK4, and TBK1).
  • These lead to cytokine production, proliferation, and survival while also leading to greater adaptive immunity.

RIG-I-like receptor (RLR) (Option A):

  • Intracellular receptors that detect viral RNA in the cytoplasm, play a crucial role in antiviral responses.
  • They do not recognize bacterial lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

C-type lectin receptor (CLR) (Option C):

  • Receptors that identify carbohydrate structures on pathogens like fungi and some bacteria.
  • They do not primarily recognize lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

NOD-like receptor 1 (NLR1) (Option D):

  • Intracellular receptors that detect bacterial peptidoglycan and other danger signals within the cytoplasm.
  • They are not the main receptors for lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

Endotoxins

  • Nature: Heat-stable lipopolysaccharides (LPS) from Gram-negative bacteria.
  • Toxicity: Depends on the lipid component (lipid A).
  • Release: Released only by cell wall disintegration.
  • Action: Effect nonspecific; action common to all endotoxins
  • Tissue Affinity: No specific tissue affinity
  • Antigenicity: Weakly antigenic
  • Neutralization: Neutralization by antibody ineffective
  • Clinical Symptoms: Fever, leucopenia, thrombocytopenia, fall in blood pressure, circulatory collapse, and bloody diarrhea leading to death.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding lipopolysaccharides (LPS) is true?

choices.text: LPS is primarily found in gram-positive bacterial cell walls.
LPS triggers an immune response through its lipid A component.
LPS is composed solely of proteins and does not contain any lipid or carbohydrate components.
LPS is composed of lipid A, lipoteichoic acid and O antigen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) LPS triggers an immune response through its lipid A component.

 

Explanation:

Lipid A, a component of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) unit, is responsible for eliciting strong immune responses, including fever and inflammation.

 

Lipopolysaccharide (LPS):

  • LPS is an important outer membrane component of gram-negative bacteria (Option A).
  • These molecules are also known as lipogylcans due to the presence of lipid and sugar molecules (Option C).
  • It consists of 3 parts (Option D):
    • O side chain (or O antigen or somatic antigen) (hydrophilic): A polysaccharide chain which greatly varies in composition between bacterial strains and hence this is used for serotyping for bacteria (e.g., Salmonella typhi - widal test). It is also a major surface antigen, induces antibody formation.
    • Core polysaccharide (hydrophilic): It is projected from lipid A region. It is composed of 10–12 sugar moieties.
    • Lipid A or the endotoxin (hydrophobic): Main virulence factor, responsible for endotoxic activities such as pyrogenicity, lethal effect, tissue necrosis, anticomplementary activity, B cell mitogenicity, adjuvant property and antitumor activity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden high fever, low blood pressure, and an erythematous rash over her body. She reports nausea, vomiting, and muscle aches. On further questioning, she recalls using tampons during her recent menstrual cycle but forgot to remove one for several days. Laboratory investigations showed catalase-positive organisms arranged in clusters. All of the following are true about the cell wall of this bacterium except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contains lipopolysaccharides

 

Explanation:

The given clinical history of retained tampons leading to high fever and rash is suggestive of toxic shock syndrome (TSS), most likely caused by Staphylococcus aureus, as the laboratory investigations revealed catalase positive organisms arranged in clusters. S. aureus is a gram positive bacteria, and gram positive bacteria does not contain lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

 

CELL WALL OF GRAM-POSITIVE BACTERIA:

  • Cell wall of gram-positive bacteria is simpler than that of gram-negative bacteria.

  • Peptidoglycan layer:
    • Much thicker (50–100 layers thick, 16–80 nm) than gram-negative cell wall (Option A).
    • Composed of a mucopeptide (murein) chain, with alternate units of NAM and NAG molecules.
    • A tetrapeptide side chain ascended from a NAM molecule is composed of L-alanine—D-glutamine—L-lysine—D-alanine. (Mnemonic-AGLA)
    • The L-lysine of one tetrapeptide chain is covalently linked to the terminal D-alanine of the adjacent chain via a pentapeptide bridge (Option C).

  • Teichoic Acid:
    • Teichoic acids are polymers which are present only in gram-positive bacteria (Option B).
    • These molecules help maintain the structure of the cell wall.
    • They are of two types: (i) Cell wall teichoic acid and (ii) Lipoteichoic acid.

Correct Answer: B) O antigen

 

Explanation

The diagram shows the cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria, and the labeled area ‘A’ refers to the O antigen (O polysaccharide).

CELL WALL OF GRAM-NEGATIVE BACTERIA:

 

  • Peptidoglycan layer:
    • It is thinner (1–2 layers, 2 nm) and more complex than the gram-positive cell wall.
    • Composed of a mucopeptide chain, with alternate NAM and NAG molecules.
    • The pentaglycine bridge is absent. The tetrapeptide chains are covalently linked betweenthe D-alanine of one chain with meso-diaminopimelic acid of the adjacent chain.

  • Outer membrane:
    • It is a phospholipid layer, attached to the thin peptidoglycan layer by a membrane protein called Braun’s lipoprotein.
    • Contains outer membrane proteins (OMP), which help in transport of small molecules.
  • Lipopolysaccharide (LPS): This layer is unique to gram-negative bacteria, consists of 3 parts (mnemonic - OPA):
    • O side chain (or O antigen or somatic antigen): A polysaccharide chain which greatly varies in composition between bacterial strains and hence this is used for serotyping for bacteria (e.g., Salmonella typhi - widal test). It is also a major surface antigen, induces antibody formation.
    • Core polysaccharide: It is projected from lipid A region. It is composed of 10–12 sugar moieties.
    • Lipid A or the endotoxin: Responsible for endotoxic activities such as pyrogenicity, tissue necrosis, anti-tumor activity, etc.
  • Periplasmic Space: It is the space between the inner cell membrane and outer membrane. It encompasses the peptidoglycan layer.
  • Cell membrane (plasma membrane):
    • The semipermeable membrane acts as an osmotic barrier and is composed of bilayered phospholipids.
    • Lacks sterols, such as cholesterol (except in Mycoplasma).
    • Site for metabolic processes like respiration and synthesis of lipids and cell walls.

 

Teichoic acids are polymers which are present only in gram-positive bacteria.

  • These molecules help maintain the structure of the cell wall.
  • They are of two types: (i) Cell wall teichoic acid and (ii) Lipoteichoic acid (Options A & D).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, who underwent mitral valve replacement 3 months ago, presents with persistent fever, fatigue, and a new heart murmur. Blood cultures reveal gram-positive cocci, and echocardiography shows vegetations on the prosthetic valve. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Staphylococcus epidermidis

 

Explanation:

The clinical history is suggestive of endocarditis and the most likely causative organism in this case is Staphylococcus epidermidis, due to the formation of biofilm over the prosthetic valve.

 

  • A biofilm is a complex structure made up of millions of bacteria that stick to surfaces and are encased in a self-produced layer of extracellular polymers, often called a polysaccharide slime layer.
  • Persistent biofilms with pathogenic bacteria can attach to damaged tissues and medical devices, like catheters and pacemakers.
  • This attachment is the first step in bacterial colonization, which can sometimes lead to infections, such as prosthetic valve endocarditis and catheter-associated urinary tract infections.

 

Biofilm advantages:

  • Helps in adherence
  • Anti- phagocytic
  • Antibiotic resistance

Examples:

  • Streptococcus mutans
    • In mouth - cause dental caries
    • Forms a biofilm over the teeth.
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis - causes prosthetic heart valve endocarditis.
  • Biofilm is also shown by Pseudomonas aeruginosa


 

Escherichia coli (Option B): This is a gram-negative bacterium typically associated with urinary tract infections and abdominal infections.

 

Streptococcus mutans (Option C): While S. mutans is part of the normal oral flora and can occasionally cause endocarditis, it is more commonly linked with native valve endocarditis after dental procedures rather than prosthetic valve infections.

 

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D): Although S. pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) can cause a range of infections, including pharyngitis and skin infections, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fever and an eschar on his arm after handling animal hides. Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the capsule of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) McFadyean reaction

 

Explanation

  • The symptoms of eschar on arms after handling animal hides is consistent with cutaneous anthrax disease.
  • It is caused by Bacillus anthracis, which has a polypeptide capsule that can be demonstrated using the McFadyean reaction.

 

Methods for Detecting Capsules

 

  • Negative Staining with India Ink and Nigrosin Stain (Option A):

The capsule is seen as clear halos around the bacteria, against a black background (image of cryptococcus).

  • McFaydean Reaction (Option C):

This method uses polychrome methylene blue stain to demonstrate the capsule of Bacillus anthracis (image amorphous purple capsule surrounding blue bacilli of B. anthracis).

  • Serological Test:

The capsular material, being antigenic, can be detected by mixing it with specific anticapsular serum.

  • Quellung Reaction (Option B):

Capsular serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae can be identified by adding antisera mixed with methylene blue, causing the capsule to swell, become refractile, and be clearly delineated (image of S. pneumoniae).

  • Capsular Antigen Detection:

Capsular antigens can be identified in samples (e.g., CSF) using a latex agglutination test (Option D) with specific anticapsular antibodies coated on latex particles, applicable for pathogens like pneumococcus, Cryptococcus, Haemophilus influenzae, and meningococcus.
